frameDefinitions: An Assessor examines a Phenomenon to figure out its Value according to some Feature of the Phenomenon.
This frame contains perception words whose Perceivers have perceptual experiences that they do not necessarily intend to.
This frame concerns a Cognizer (a person or other intelligent being) paying close attention to something, the Ground, in order to discover and note its salient characteristics.
An Agent changes a Patient's ability to resist literal or figurative attack.
A Cognizer construes an Item as belonging to a certain Category.

A Cognizer possesses knowledge about the workings, significance, or meaning of an idea or object, which we call Phenomenon, and is able to make predictions about the behavior or  occurrence of the Phenomenon.
frameExamples: Each company is then <t>evaluated</t> for their earning potential. CNI
Abashed, realising that he had <t>overheard</t> her conversation with Victoria, Sheeley didn't try to make excuses.
We <t>searched</t> the yard  for my contact lens.
We <t>bulwarked</t> the castle against the oncoming horde.
You 've already <t>stereotyped</t> me as a bimbo, have n't you?
I figured this out last week and now I really <t>understand</t> it.
listRoleDefinitions: The sentient entity that evaluates the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
The entity whose <fen>Value</fen> according to a <fen>Feature</fen> is being measured.
The type of property or feature that the <fen>Phenomenon</fen> is being judged on.
An event or procedure that allows the <fen>Assessor</fen> to evaluate the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the physical entity or channel used by the <fen>Assessor</fen> to make the assessment.
The time at which the <fen>Assessor</fen> makes the assessment.
The location where the assessing takes place.
This role is the being who has a perceptual experience, not necessarily on purpose. It is typically expressed as an External Argument.
This role is the entity or phenomenon that the perceiver experiences with his or her senses. It is typically expressed as Object with verbs.
The <fen>Body_part</fen> is the location on the <fen>Perceiver_passive</fen>'s body where the perceptual experience  takes place.  It is typically expressed in a PP.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Perceiver_passive</fen> or the <fen>Body_part</fen> perceives the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
The general location within which the act of perception takes place.
The <fen>Cognizer</fen> pays attention to an entity in order to discover something about it. The role is normally expressed as an External Argument:

The <fen>Cognizer</fen> pays attention to the <fen>Ground</fen>, so named because it serves as the background or context for the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>. This role can be expressed as an NP Object or as a PP Complement.

The <fen>Medium</fen> is the piece of text or work in which the <fen>Cognizer</fen> pays attention to an entity in order to discover something about it. The role is normally expressed as an External Argument:
An entity directed by the <fen>Cognizer</fen>  that interacts with the <fen>Ground</fen> to accomplish the scrutiny.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Cognizer</fen> is scrutinizing the <fen>Ground</fen>.
The <fen>Agent</fen> makes the <fen>Patient</fen> more resistant to attack.
The <fen>Patient</fen> is the entity that is being made more resistant.
An event which causes the <fen>Patient</fen> to become more resistant.
The time at which the <fen>Agent</fen> makes the <fen>Patient</fen> more resistant.
The location at which the <fen>Agent</fen> makes the <fen>Patient</fen> more resistant.
This is the person who performs an act of categorization. Typically, this frame element is expressed as an External Argument.
This is the entity which is construed or treated by the <fen>Cognizer</fen> as being an instance of a particular <fen>Category</fen>. Typically, the <fen>Item</fen> is expressed as an Object.

This frame element expresses a general type or class of which the <fen>Item</fen> is considered an instance. Typically, it is expressed in a prepositional phrase headed by <ment>as</ment> or <ment>under</ment>.

This frame element expresses properties of the <fen>Item</fen> which is used as a basis for categorization. <fen>Criteria</fen> are the general dimensions along which <fen>Item</fen>s can potentially differ from one another and hence, fall into different <fen>Category</fen>s. For example, a paint sample can be classified <ment>by color</ment> or <ment>by finish (matte or gloss)</ment>; if they are classified by color, one can be classified <ment>as orange</ment> and another <ment>as red</ment>. The <fen>Criteria</fen> role is typically expressed as a PP headed by <ment>by</ment>, or as a complex PP of the form <ment>on the basis of...</ment>:
This Frame Element marks expressions that indicate when a certain Categorization was made.
The sentient animate being who acquires new knowledge.
A state of affairs or dynamic system whose internal make-up and working the Cognizer comes to assimilate into their knowledge structure.
A part  of a person's cognitive-emotional faculties that is said to acquire knowledge.
This role indicates the when the <fen>Cognizer</fen> asssimilates the new knowledge.
listRoleExamples: You will also be graded <fex>on your speed of response</fex> .
<fex>The study</fex> evaluated the risk of a major quake.
<fex>This chapter</fex> evaluates the far-left's contribution to the environmentalism debate since the '70's .
The committee rated Smithers ' most loyal servant ' <fex>about a week ago</fex> .
They 'll evaluate you <fex>in that room over there</fex> , and then you 're free to go .
<fex>The waiter</fex> smelled something foul in the kitchen.
The waiter smelled <fex>something foul</fex> in the kitchen.
Marlow felt something cold and hard <fex>against the back of his neck</fex>.
<fex>Leslie</fex> examined the glass for cracks.
Leslie examined <fex>the glass</fex> for cracks.
<fex>Chapter four</fex> examined the case for free speech.
The temperature controller monitored the temperature <fex>with a calibrated silicon diode</fex>.
<fex>Kim</fex> categorized the books under fiction. <fex>Kim</fex> categorized them on the basis of genre.
Kim categorized <fex>the books</fex> under fiction.
Kim categorized the book <fex>as/under fiction</fex>.
The students were categorized <fex>on the basis of their test scores</fex>.
<fex>20 years ago</fex> people would consider this as nothing unusual
<fex>Sue</fex> grasped the essentials right away
You must grasp <fex>the complex relationship of all these subjects to each other</fex>
<fex>My heart</fex> grasped that reality immediately.
<fex>Yesterday</fex> the students finally grasped the meaning of the equation
